page.title: 05River Ock
page.content: Fields bordering the River Ock were once marsh, and were subject to winter flooding, until the river level was lowered in 1979. Unfortunately, from the farmer's point of view, lowering the level drained Bagmere Pond. Where the River Ock passes through Charney Bassett, there has been much work done dredging and cleaning the river. In 1974 it was diverted in places. There is a stone bridge over the river, and by the side there is an area of grass (with seats), which is much used by children for fishing and to paddle their feet in the water. Where the river flows through Lyford, it is about 10 feet wide, and flows strongly. Due to heavy pollution of the Thames salmon have not been here since the turn of the century. A valued delicacy- the freshwater crayfish - is still obtainable in places.
